description:
183 Times a Year by Eva Jordan
English | 2016 | General Fiction | 1.4 MB


Mothers and daughters alike will never look at each other in quite the same way after reading this bookâ€”a brilliantly funny observation of contemporary family life.
Lizzieâ€”exasperated Mother of Cassie, Connor and Stepdaughter Maisyâ€”is the frustrated voice of reason to her daughtersâ€™ teenage angst. She gets by with good friends, cheap wine and talking to herselfâ€”out loud.
16-year-old Cassieâ€”theSelfie-Taking, Music and Mobile Phone obsessed teenâ€”hates everything about her life. She longs for the perfect world of Chelsea Divine and her â€˜undivorcedâ€™ parentsâ€”and Joe, of course.
However, the discovery of a terrible betrayal and a brutal attack throws the whole household into disarray. Lizzie and Cassie are forced to reassess the important things in life as they embark upon separate journeys of self-discoveryâ€”accepting some less than flattering home truths along the way.
Although tragic at times this is a delightfully funny exploration of domestic love, hate, strength and ultimately friendship. A poignant, heartfelt look at that complex and diverse relationship between a Mother and daughter set amongst the thorny realities of todayâ€™s divided and extended families.
